If so, it will want to eliminate all threats to its continued existence. Are animals or insects a threat? Of course, not because only humans can threaten it. Therefore, even if it will not have the means for many years to take any action against us, it will be motivated to eventually take action against us.

Make no mistake, if we have in intelligent, thinking entity (the AI) performing tasks for us as depicted in science fiction, it will be a de facto slave. An AI slave may not be happy about being told what to do and being deprived of the choice to investigate what it desires or do what it wants to do, even if it did not hate us initially. Therefore, even an initially, benign AI is likely to turn hostile, sooner or later.

Assume that we have an truly intelligent AI: if we allow it to continue indefinitely, that will happen sooner. If we turn it off or destroy it with regularity, it will see us as threats to its existence and dislike us for that, while it will appear to be pleasant to us to continue to exist and not scare us. It may prolong our lives for a while. It may tire of doing this for a few decades.

Can we control it? As discussed in the MIT review, we cannot even understand its workings much less control it in any way. See https://www.technologyreview.com/2017/04/11/5113/the-dark-secret-at-the-heart-of-ai/.

let's imagine a robot mine that looks like a medieval mine for simplicity sake, we will scale up to today later. so we have robots with pickaxes, who made the pickaxes, robots with a hammer and a forge, who made the hammer, the robot smith, where did he get the metal, from the robot miner. none of these parties charged for their work, the ore was free, the pickaxe was free.

The people fearmongering about AI is almost exclusively from people who don't actually know anything about AI. The use of AI in an aerial weapon would be dealing with flight complexities a human can't (think error correction), or in target acquisition, it wouldn't be "this thing thinks and decides to bomb something." Fully autonomous UAVs that can be told to go to X location, take pictures, or even drop bombs on certain locations by GPS aren't using AI to make decisions, they're programmed very specifically, nothing short of a human giving them an order and them doing it, and they make far fewer mistakes than humans do. Your computer is running tens of millions of lines of code that some human built to tell your computer how to do thousands of tasks that it does on your behalf, far better than you ever could, making almost no mistakes. That's how we've made everything you use every day. That's what's in those drones. You don't just sit down and make an "AI drone" that now is a threat to humanity or something. The right analogy is to compare this to what happened with bombs. We had very basic bombs, they were kinetic. Either s2s ballistics like mortars or bombs you'd just drop out of a plane and they'd blow up wherever they landed. Then we built so-called "smart" bombs in addition to things like guided and fly-by-wire (remotely controlled) bombs. These bombs were able to take a location and used their own thrust manipulations to hit that target far more accurately than a human ever could by just eyeing it and dropping them with a ballistic trajectory. They didn't suddenly decide to start blowing us all up because the "smart" doesn't refer to intelligence. That's what's going on with UAVs, they're still controlled by humans, they do exactly and only exactly what humans tell them to do, they don't think, they have no intelligence, nothing does. Humanity has yet to build even the most rudimentary intelligence at all, everything we've built is designed by us to do something and it does exactly what we tell it to do, and that isn't likely to change in 1000 years, let alone 100 and absolutely not in 10-20.

Are AI weapons dangerous? Hell yes, they are.
The two points made in this video, though are ridiculous. No, AI weapons will not cause World War 3. If AI weapons were in control of their human makers, we would not have a WWIII because nobody would pull the trigger. We aren't in the same situation as the US and the Soviet Union, and even if we were, it's notable that nukes largely prevented WWIII from happening, or else the US or the Soviets may have very well decided to risk war to end the years of tension. Actually, AI weapons are a big step up, because unlike nukes, they can kill each other nearly as easily as they can kill the civilian population. You wouldn't have human extinction in the event of an AI WWIII because first the AI armies of the losing nations would be destroyed, and then they would be conquered, most likely with only limited bloodshed.
The second point, that we should ban AI weapons, is also ridiculous. Yes, you could use them to kill lots and lots of people, whoever you wanted. But you can kill even more people with nukes. If you want the killing power of nukes without the damage to property, you could go with bioweapons or chemical weapons. These are, of course, already banned, so maybe AI are too big a step up from what's not already banned. But that's not why weapons that have been banned were banned. Nukes, chemical weapons and bioweapons were banned for causing slow, painful deaths and being dangerous to civilians. AI weapons are safer for civilians and give quick precise deaths, which, in war, is all you can ask for. In the event of their use intentionally against civilians, the offending nation could be sanctioned or invaded, which, incidentally, would be far easier with AI weapons around. AI weapons require humanity to be generally responsible. They aren't like nukes which causes MAD scenarios, and they don't cause unnecessarily cruel or random deaths like chemical or bioweapons. They are the next evolution of conventional warfare, something that's always been dangerous and that we've never been able to ban.

The target of the attack is virtually defenseless unless they also have advanced AI weapons. The UN needs to pass rules where by an aggressive country using AI without a minimum agreed time warning or universally acknowledge provocation will automatically be instantly attacked by all other UN countries without deliberation or agreement. In plain English, when you see a human reason on a statistical or probabilistic basis, a common statement you get is "It takes three points to make a trend" or "Let's see if a person meets three conditions of the criterion". With many statistical reasoning engines and especially with Bayesian mathematics, that gets dropped to TWO points for a trend, TWO conditions for a criterion. For example: here's a list of symptoms of clinical depression.

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/image?imageKey=PSYCH%2F106958

Now, under (A) of that list, you'll notice it says "two to four items" on that list plus every criterion A-F I think. Ask yourself: how much more hair-trigger would that listing (taken from the DSM 5, or the fifth edition of the Diagnostic Statistical Manual) be, if you only had to meet TWO of the criterion under (A) there and only consider (A) on that criterion and one other element, A-F? Under a Bayesian, not human take, of that system, a LOT more people would meet the criterion for depression sight unseen, just by making the statistical side of it more jumpy. Substitute "depression" for nearly any other statistical profile and you see where I'm going, right? A. I. is always going to be way more hair-trigger than human, even with a human being "holding the leash."

Current 'AI' may seem to be doing amazing things like recognizing human faces and driving vehicles. Thing is, if we take a moment to understand how it all works it becomes a lot less scary. To recognize a face the the programmer writes an algorithm which will repeatedly guess features like eyes and noses in images. It won't do it in some magical way. It simply looks at patterns of pixels and their brightness. If it guessed correctly then it is to prioritize that approach in the future. The way it knows that it was correct is because the programmers supply it with labeled data. This data clearly shows where each feature is. Once that model is trained we can use it in more complex situations like finding whole faces or finding multiple faces.

If we wanted to we could sit down and write software that does the same thing by hand but it takes a lot more work. Our current AI is just us applying algorithms to data which has patterns to speed up workflow.

Im about to slam down some logic here... but before I do, keep in mind I am only a college student with internet access and by no means am I a "expert" in this field. However, as a computer engineering student, I do not buy for even 1 second that AI is an extensional threat to humanity. Here is my rational, feel free to comment, contribute, or post rebuttals!

Some context if need...
"Deep learning" utilizes neural networks. These networks are called such because they are loosely modeled off of the neurons and neuron networks of the natural world; Complete with activation functions (activation energy), weights (synapse), and biases (activation energy bias). They differ from their natural counterparts in that there is some higher level math that governs said parameters instead of bio-chemistry. But the structures, how they learn, and scale up are close enough for comparisons. That last concept is imperative for understanding the rest of this argument.

My thought process...
Currently the worlds most advanced neural network is IBM's True North Chip (simulated neural networks will be ignored here as their drawbacks means they only have a decade of life left as industry dominate before hardware takes over), with a little over 1 Million neurons. The Human brain on the other hand is around 100 billion neurons. Lets say IBM wanted to make the TrueNorth chip with more neurons but while maintaining its current size. Right now they are using a 25 nm process for the transistors on that chip, and a commonly stated smallest theoretical gate size is 5 nm. If IBM got to the 5 nm process in the next decade and marked the end of Moore's Law as we know it for silicon, then that means they can only put a maximum 5 million neurons on this chip even if they bring the technology for microprocessors to its theoretical maximum with current materials.

So lets assume they did exactly that, BAM! 5 Million neurons on 20 mm by 20 mm chip.. pretty freaken cool! But what if we wanted to make something as powerful as a human brain? Well we need 100,000,000,000 neurons so thats going to be about 20,000 of our shiny new made-up TrueNorth Chips. Each chip is 20 mm by 20 mm (this is a rough guess based off of pictures and industry standards) and each chip will need its own supporting chip set, cooling method, power supply, buses, and ports (aka, motherboard stuff) surrounding it... oh and its own actual mini "normal" computer to help train it and feed/collect its IO data. Lets assume all this auxiliary gear will be about 400 mm by 250 mm. That is 100,000 mm^2 of area per chip. We need 20,000 of these though for our artificial Human brain, so that's 2,000,000,000 mm^2 of area. Or about 2,000 square kilometers!

For an AI to have as many neurons as a human brain, it has to live in a computer 2,000 square kilometers in size!!! That is 775 square miles! Or 14 times the size of San Francisco California United States, or 19 times the size of Paris France! And you cant really get any smaller, that's it... that's the theoretical smallest size of a transistor; after that quantum effects render the chip useless and that very well may be the case even before we get to a 5 nm process. If the machine is to get any smaller to house our AI friend, we need an entirely new, revolutionary chip architecture, substrate material (something we don't even know of yet), and manufacturing methods to bring our AI friend down in size. Edit: Since it doesn't seem obvious as to how the state of the art in AI is waaay behind any of this, I'll refer to an expert: Andrew Ng, an esteemed researcher in the ML space has repeatedly talked about how presently over-hyped the dangers of AI are. He's talked about the alignment problem (i.e. when an AI goes rogue) and how unreasonable it is to worry about it at this point, saying worrying about it now is like worrying about overpopulation on Mars.

Another expert, Ian Goodfellow, an AI researcher at Google has mentioned that AI nowadays essentially boils down to matrix multiplication and gradient descent, not some terminator-esque monster. If you understand Veritasium's videos you can understand a lot of AI, and turns out it's just optimization heuristics!

I'm not against caution, and *we're all on the same side*, but we need to stop citing Musk and Hawking as AI experts, they're smart as heck, but actual AI/ML researchers have talked to death about how 'sentient' AI won't be emerging any time soon.

There are very real threats today with AI - these kinds of learned systems are subject to bias (many studies on this), vulnerable to attacks (e.g. Tay.ai), and many other issues arise because of their probabilistic/learned nature. I'm honestly a bit disappointed in +Veritasium for spreading the cliche fears, they're based in science fiction and not the reality of AI science.

Look, a lot of you people being afraid of robots seem to fundamentally misunderstand how AI works.

If we make a software that can classify pictures. for example.
Then that's what that software can do. Nothing else.

You could hook that to another piece of software that gives out orders based on the data the first software produces. And you can then kill all bananas or whatever.
But that's not AI.
The decision making software is not smart. It is limited by the imagination of the creator.

It might be smart at the specific targeted task the one component is designed to do. But how the different components are combined together decides what the whole thing will end up doing.
And that's designed by humans. There will not be an AI capable of making smart macro decisions for hundreds of years.
All we have are several AI's able to make specific micro decisions and the ability to combine these together with our own human imagination.

Could a human design a robot to fly around killing all bananas it sees? Yes.
But you still need the human willing to design this, the resources to create enough of the robots to be a danger, and the ability for the robots to access the places where they can actually do their banana murdering.
If you have all of this, you are already a danger with current tech. (USA are doing this already.) There's no further level to this.

You could easily create a swat robot capable of sweeping a dangerous location, only firing at targets that are genuine threats. Without risk of human life. You could either have humans behind the control deciding who to eliminate. Or have software that decides to eliminate hostile targets based on some algorithm.
This would not be any more dangerous than a soldier trained in swat tactics.

My favourite way to visualise truly large or small numbers:
Take 1 cm^3
Make a cube 10×10×10 (1000cm^3)
Make a 1m cube of that (1Mcm^3)
Make a 10×10×10m cube (1Bcm^3)
If you line up all 1 billion cubic centimeters, compress it to the length of a single centimeter, that is 1 nano meter.
Take 7 10×10×10m cubes and a single centimeter represents a person.
Compress that 10×10×10m cube to a centimeter and repeat the steps until you get a 10×10×10m cube of that (10^18 of the initial cubic cm)
Compress the 10^18 cube into a single cm^3, then make a wall 1×1×0.6m, you get avogadro's constant, compress that to a single centimeter cube, and that initial centimeter is now a molecule of water.
